name: Wolf 1061
scenarioDescription:
The Wolf 1061 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Wolf 1061 is a star with 0.29 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.31 times its radius. It is located 14.06 light years away from the solar system.

Wolf 1061 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Wolf 1061 system


Wolf 1061 b

Wolf 1061 b was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Wolf 1061 b is 1.9111799999999999 times the mass of Earth. At 1.9111799999999999 Earth masses, Wolf 1061 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


Wolf 1061 c

Wolf 1061 c was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Wolf 1061 c is 3.41214 times the mass of Earth. At 3.41214 Earth masses, Wolf 1061 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Its semi-major axis is 0.47 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Wolf 1061 d is 7.70514 times the mass of Earth. At 7.70514 Earth masses, Wolf 1061 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Wolf 1061, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by La Silla Observatory.
